title: Year after Long Island's close, homeless services are still lacking in Boston - Massachusetts news
text:
After determing that the crumbling bridge connecting Long Island to the mainland was no longer safe, city officials closed it, shuttering shelters that served the city’s recovering addicts and homeless population. Still, a year later, crucial beds have yet to be replaced, and many remain uprooted and displaced.
More than 700 people who sought shelter on the island were dispersed through the city when the bridge unexpectedly closed, according to The Boston Globe . They slept on mats in overcrowded spaces, in doorways or on steps, and in the surrounding woods.
Related Links Boston’s Homeless Rely on Each Other to Survive Record Winter Crime follows homeless shelter to Newmarket area While the city has spent millions trying to replace the Long Island resources and beds that once served recovering addicts and homeless residents, more than 100 recovery and detox beds have yet to be replaced, The Globe reported. At least four people who received shelter and care from a program on Long Island have died since its closure, which critics say could have been prevented if they had a stable environment.
